I ever tell you about the time my buddy Keith made sushi? Yeah, his mom took him to a sushi place for his birthday and he didn't want to go, but he turned out he LOVED it, man. But it's like 10 bucks a su-sho in one of them places, so Keith figures, "Hey, how hard can it be to roll up some raw food in seaweed," right? As it turns out, it's hard. Now, they say experience is the best teacher, and experience taught Keith that if you ever eat three pounds of raw chicken, it kills you. Now luckily, Keith's brain went into self-defense mode and started shutting organs down to head the chicken off at the pass, and the doctors were able to get 'em out before his heart stopped. But to this day, Keith has no sensation in his right foot, and he doesn't recognize his own brother Paul no more.

I remember this game through my siblings eyes and always loved the characters, campaigns, visuals, and the fun chaos between the players irl. And now that I've gotten to play myself, I'll you tell that I wasn't just reminiscing about my experiences through rose tinted glasses. L4D2 is simple to pick up for anybody, even for ones that don't play games. And with the main aspect being the Co-operation between players, more experienced players can easily guide newer players through the game without having to carry them or leaving them to fend for themselves (or complain that "the noobs" are just holding them back but it's not the games fault). Another plus is the replay value. When starting out with the game, you easily pick the mechanics and glide through one of the campaigns you're playing. But as you get better, the less supplies that given to you and more hordes are thrown at you, all in the same difficulty. And this is all thanks to the game's director. The Director Basically controls what happens during the campaign based on your performance. If you're breezing through the level, supplies will be scarce and more hordes and special infected your way. It might even send in an extra tank! But if you're struggling, more supplies will appear and there will be less infected. This is all because of the director, giving the game a fresh and new experience each time you play a campaign. This isn't even going into everything else like overwhelming amount of attention to details, The map designs and the modding community just to name a few! This game is cult classic and will leave a legacy for future generations as one of the best to stand against the passage of times while leaving the others......

I'm sure there are mods that even disable gore or just make the game less violent in general if gore and blood in general isn't your thing but cooperative shooters are. Heavy emphasis on "cooperative" because you absolutely need your team in order to survive, unlike most other cooperative shooters, unless you're the less than one percent that can complete the last human on earth mode

[b] (note: this game was gifted to me i could have a bias cause i like getting games for free) [/b]

[h1] The Gameplay [/h1]
The game is well, what it says; A zombie shooter with 5 new expansive campaigns, with a story to play through. Some complaints I have is sometimes the witch gets triggered for no reason or the game just summons tons of tanks on me unexpectedly during Zombie Hordes.

[h1] The Story [/h1]
I can't really comment much on it as I haven't payed too much attention to the story (because all I wanted was just "The funny zombie shooter with co-op and versus" which well, is what the game is), but why does Whitaker want Cola so badly in a Zombie Apocalypse ğŸ’€ğŸ’€

[h1] Other stuff [/h1]
Now, Here's my favourite thing about the game: [b] The modding community. [/b]
There are [u] TONS [/u] of funny mods that really just makes the experience more fun and stupid (especially in a voice-chat with friends), Such as Sans from UNDERTALE as coach. 
There are mods that just give you infinite first-aid kits/other helpful items if you suck at the game that much. 
And if for any reason you wanted Quagmire from Family Guy over the tank, then there's a mod for that, too.

My only complaint is that there are lots of 18+/NSFW mods which i'm not gonna delve into for obvious reasons.

[h1] Verdict/Final result [/h1]
Recommended. The game is very fun with friends, i'd say it's 13+ (though I think I have the cut version so maybe 15-16 would be prefered(?) ), and make sure you're careful when on the Steam Workshop for the game.

This game is masterpiece.I bought it for  under 2 euro,and i am amazed.The game has so many cool and  realistic things like:
- you can see sometimes zombies vomiting
- if you shoot zombie in the leg,while it's running,the zombie will jump and then will fall on the ground like a bag
- windows don't break with one bullet(or maybe only sometimes)
- if you shoot zombie in stomach with shotgun,there is a chance that his organs will fall of the stomach
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The campaign is amazing.Every mission is connected with the previous one.
Multiplayer modes are also fun.Mutation is one of the best gamemodes.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
I recommend this game 100%.

Left 4 Dead 2 is proof that sometimes, less is more. No skill trees, no leveling system, no loot mechanics, and no card nonsense. It's just you, three other chucklefucks, and a ton of zombies. The special infected provide plenty of incentive to stick together, but splitting off to scrounge for that extra bottle of pills or medkit is legitimately enticing too. The AI director keeps things fresh even on the same campaigns (which is a good thing because people LOVE No Mercy, Dead Center and Dark Carnival) and of course there's the modding scene. Because if you haven't mowed down hordes of teletubbies as the cast of Madoka Magica using a cat as an SMG that is reloaded with chin scratches, have you really lived?

This is a game that has aged incredibly well despite it being a 10 year old zombie game. Between the popular modding scene, fast paced and exciting gameplay, well done horror elements and robust modes, its no wonder this game has hardly slowed down since release.

The reason Left 4 Dead 2 still has not been topped despite having a shinier, more polished pseudo reboot in Back 4 Blood is because Left 4 Dead 2 already mastered the art of being simple but endlessly entertaining. This is not to say L4D2 is a mindless game, however, it is not necessarily complex either. You and 3 other survivors. whether they are bots or real people. need to race to the end of each level in a campaign in order to survive against hordes of basic and special infected, the latter which can be controlled by human players in a head to head mode. This sounds like it can get boring and repetitive quickly, however, due to an AI called "The Director", games can dynamically become harder and more intense depending on what has been happening during the campaign. This makes campaigns somewhat different every time you play. This is in combination with good level design that gives both humans and infected opportunities for strategy and victory, but also the variety of special infected that, if played right, can seriously cripple the humans. Levels and campaigns are continuous and tense tug of war battles between both parties that are always exciting.

This game is like a diner in town that serves great food that you've eaten since you were a kid. The food isn't fancy, but every time you go, it never gets old and is always a great spot to go to with friends.

where do i start, where do i start...
If you are a adult or parent reading this review to find out if this game is good for you/your kid, then listen closely.

yes.

very much.

this game is 4-player cooperative shooter, and not like the generic ones like cod or overwatch where you are SUPPOSE to work together and instead you end up running off and competing to get the biggest kill streak because "It doesn't matter if i lost, i racked up a huge KD."
because when you put those players into left 4 dead 2?

they're going to die quicker than it takes for you to say "no" to someone asking you to buy a fidget spinner.

so if your getting this game for you and your friends, or you and your kid. go for it! this is one hell of a fun game for families and friends. it'll teach your dull little youngling that "running away and showing off how cool his stunts are" the lesson he needs to learn. ACTUAL. TEAMWORK.

if your worried about it getting boring? throw that thought out right now and listen to me. because you'd be crazy to think this is boring (i've played this for 10 years on the xbox... haha...)

first of all (if your playing on pc), you get access to 14 campaigns, around 40 mutations (which are basically modifiers of the campaigns that either make them more fun or make you scream in fear because your running away from 10 tanks), a well made versus mode (just dont play online first, because the community is a little unforgiving if you havent gotten any experience with versus mode), scavenge (which is basically endless but with a twists, you and 3 other people have to scavenge out for gas cans to make sure the time limit you have til the round ends keeps going, there could be up to 14 - 36 gas cans and if you find them all, you get the maximum amount of points, but dont just go running out there while not expecting anything, because your up against a team of 4 who are playing as special infected, if the time runs out, it counts the total gas cans you collected. then switches teams so that its you as the special infected, trying to stop the other team from getting more points.), and surval and survival versus (basically endless + endless mode but formatted like versus).

and ontop of that, have you heard of the workshop?
the workshop is a community page linked to most source engine games. (such as gmod, tf2, ect.)
it allows someone to make addons (basically moderations) to the game.
dont worry, it doesnt mean you have to know anything about modding, the community has done it for you.
in the workshop you can download custom campaigns, survivor skins (this time for free entirely and not for vbucks or something), gun skins (not just a dumb paintjob, but a whole new model such as turning the pistol into buzzlighter.), ui changes, ect.
Basically anything, and the way you do this is you find the addon you want. click on it, scroll to the green subscribe button, and click it. yeah, thats it.
no coding no exporting no unzipping, nothing. just click the green button and your game installs it for you.

oh and if your wanting a description of everything

oh my god never before have my ears experienced so much pleasure when shooting zombies.
the gun sounds are the most realistic than every game that has come out since Left 4 dead 2.

Left 4 Dead 2 is a 4 player first person shooter where you and 3 others must cooperate to survive a horde of zombies. Or you can play alone and suffer with the NPC's. The gameplay isn't too bad and can be quite fun at some moments. It doesn't get "boring" until you've been playing for a very long time. 

The zombies can vary from standard zombies to zombies that spit acid and pin players down. I DO have an issue with some of them though. The Smokers, Hunters, Jockeys, and Chargers are all zombies that can pin you down and confirm a kill on you if you team doesn't help you out fast enough. This can get extremely frustrating when you split from the group to grab part of an objective, or when the NPC's fail to help you out.

Getting pinned is an easy confirmed kill if you aren't near your team at all, and it can get quite annoying when you barely survive one pin, just to get pinned again a split second after. And these enemies are littered ALL over the place, making it a pain to go anywhere thats remotely far from an ally. Though I guess you could make the argument that it helps "team play", which I guess it does, but it still isn't too enjoyable to need to be saved over and over again.

This game is really great, if you have not already given it a try for some reason then you should totally do so. 

From game-modes like the standard campaign to versus, survival, mutations, etc. There is endless amounts of fun to be had. 

Another great aspect of playing the game has to be the workshop mods. The workshop mods allow for even more entertainment value to be relived in runs.  

Playing this game with friends has to be one of the most fun things you can experience in a multiplayer game. 

I have about 157 hours put into this game so far, and with that being said I recommend this game to anyone looking for a fun zombie game out there, you will not regret your purchase.

10/10

Left 4 Dead 2 is a timeless classic which still holds up extremely well with it's newer competitors. Playing through all campaigns from start to finish would only take you a day or two, but it's replayability means that sinking 100 hours or more into the game is almost certain.  I have probably played the Dark Carnival campaign 15 times since I brought the game and am yet to grow tired of it.

The graphics and audio are pretty average, nothing to get excited over. However, they don't hinder the game in any way.

This game is beginner friendly, with the bots proving very helpful in the easier levels. Although, if you play on advanced or expert, the bots become a huge disadvantage, you're better off playing online. The community has some toxic people, as do all communities, but in general, is very welcoming and kind.

Aside from the standard campaign mode, there are specifically online modes such as scavenge and versus. Although I enjoy the concept of versus, the infected are quite difficult to control in comparison to the survivors which can be pretty frustrating.

The one BIG drawback I would say about this game is it can be pretty buggy at times. Especially if you're an achievement hunter. Multiple times I've been playing with friends where they've got an achievement and I haven't for seemingly no reason. It can be pretty frustrating especially if it's a long winded achievement.

 Overall, this is one of my favourite games. Whether you're in the mood to grind for achievements or just play casually, this game will appeal to you. At the time of writing this review it's on sale but even if it wasn't I'd implore anyone to buy it since it is 100% worth the price.

This is probably my favorite PC game of all time. I love the combination of drama, comedy, and fear. The setting of rural Louisiana is very cool too--and I'm from that area! I keep coming back to L4D2 every year or two. 

For the zombie genre, this game is perfect. The controls are smooth, the level designs are all unique and interesting, the challenge scales itself somewhat as well. The "director" feature makes replays dynamic and keeps a player on his toes. L4D2 has some daytime zombie levels whereas L4D1 were all at night. I think my favorite level is The Bridge--that final scene is just so crazy!! I love replaying that one.

When buying this game, one also receives the Left 4 Dead 1 levels, which is a great game in itself! Overall, it's an incredible value!

Great gameplay, mostly god awful fandom attached to it. :)

The amount of weeb garbage in the steam workshop makes me want projectile vomit like a boomer. The flashlight attached to you can barely light a room, much less help you see. And remember when I said god awful fandom? Well there are plenty of awful random nobodies that join public lobbies, that join only to make your gameplay experience insufferable. (Quick side note: the amount of plagiarism and art theft in this community is disgusting.)

Also, Versus mode is objectively the worst mode in the game, it's so one-sided I swear it was designed to attract the most toxic, racist, and judgemental S H I T H E A D S to join those lobbies and make both sides suffer. My recommendation: Download a lot of your favorite mods, replace your crap ass vanilla flashlight with a useful flashlight mod, avoid public lobbies like a plauge, create a private lobby for your friends to join you, and actually have fun!

Final verdict: 9/10
Random nobodies who like to make other players suffer with no justifiable reasons: 0/10 :)

1/4 cup white sugar
1/4 cup light brown sugar
6 oz chocolate chips, I used milk chocolate â€“ semi sweet is good as well
1 tbsp milk
1 tsp baking soda
8 tbsp unsalted butter, room temperature
2 tsp vanilla extract
1.5 cup gluten free flour, I used King Arthur Gluten Free All Purpose Flour Measure for Measure â€“ with xanthan gum
1 large egg

In the bowl of a stand mixer, place the paddle attachment and begin to beat the room temperature unsalted butter. It will help when you then add the light brown sugar and the white sugar to the bowl. Mix them together for around 5 minutes on a medium high.
Scrape the sides of your bowl and make sure everything is incorporated. Add the egg and beat together for around 3 more minutes. The mix may look a bit curdled however it is totally fine. Add the vanilla extract and the milk and beat for 30 more seconds.
Add the gluten free flour and baking soda. Toss in the chocolate chips and mix until the cookie dough comes together. Place parchment paper (or a baking mat) onto your baking sheets. Make sure they are a few inches apart (if you do not place them a few inches apart, then you may end up with one massive cookie when you bake them).
Take your prepared baking sheets and use a cookie scoop to scoop the gluten free cookie dough balls and place them onto the baking sheets. Roll the cookie dough balls if you feel they are a bit off with their shape. Place the baking sheets in the fridge or the freezer for 1 hour.
Preheat the oven to 350 f and when it reaches the appropriate temperature bake the cookies for 11-12 minutes. They will be a nice golden brown on the top. If you are worried that they are not quite done, lift the cookies and if the bottoms are golden brown then they are likely done. It may be that your oven rack is just too low.
You can allow them to cool completely on the baking sheet or transfer them to a wire rack to cool. You can store these cookies in an airtight container on the counter for 5-7 days or in the freezer for 3 months. If you freeze them, then you can bust out the best gluten free chocolate chip cookies whenever you have a craving over the next 90 days!

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

This game, is hands down the best zombie games out there.
This game is one of those zombie games that are actually original (and fun), if you have the time and money to purchase this game then do it. Trust me, your money will be worth this game.
This game has it all: Survival mode, Campaign mode, Versus mode, Realism mode (if you favor a challenge when playing campaigns, Scavenge mode, Survival Versus mode, and even more special gamemodes.
And if you're a fan of Counter Strike, they even got the guns from the game (AWP, MP5, Scout, Krieg 552 (SG 552). Not only that, but the game is super easy to mod and the creativity of the workshop is crazy. Would you like to kill infected zombies with grenade launchers and chainsaws? Or, do you want to kill infected zombies with a Pepsi can launcher that is loaded with mentos, Of course you do!
Like bro, you can play the Resident Evil games on L4D2 through mods, though it won't be 100% accurate to the game for obvious reasons.
I hope this review was good, and persuaded you enough to think about purchasing the game if you haven't already.

Left 4 Dead 2 is purely an amazing game with good characters, good gameplay, great level design, and overall a lot of active players to this day. It's definitely worth getting this game.
Still one of the best games I ever played.

Left 4 Dead 2 is not a game you ever stop playing, you just take a few years to remember what reality is actually like until you delve back into the insanity of a modded Left 4 Dead game. I spent about 4 years taking a break from the hustle of playing Pc games, but when i finally jumped on Steam again, the first thing I wanted to do was to return to playing Hentai games. The second thing I wanted to do was get back into this masterpiece of a game.

If your worried that this 13 year old game might set your PC alight and kill you and your neighbours in the explosion, dont worry, the game still looks pretty good by modern standards circa 2022, yet even that guy who crashes playing Morrowind while talking shit about how great his PC is because Rakesh at the Dell store told him so, can play this game.

The game play, is well designed. After playing the game for a hundred hours or so you will learn how the game works, how zombie hordes spawn and how they are completely different from regular zombies. Every special infected has its own sound cue to let you know when they've spawned, I dont remember what half of these sound like since I've modded them to play Brittany Spears, or the less horrifying Ear rape of a monkey man sticking his penis in my ear. For reference anything under Expert difficulty is meant for children, are you a child? Im hope not. Why are you playing this game? I feel incredibly sorry for you, and I'm sure your parents will take full responsibility for your impending developmental issues.

The community itself, is incredibly hit and miss. I've had games with incredibly nice and sociable people, which as an introvert is an incredibly uncomfortable experience. I've also had games of expert with people who started screaming at me that committing suicide on a 3rd down is an optimal strategy, and that I'm effectively gimping myself by not using the defibrillator early on, for its 50/100 permanent health, and that instead of playing the game I should consider the rope.

In summary I give this game a very good score. It reminds me of the days when we had a variety of fun games. Before the fall of the Roman empire, which sent us tumbling into the dark ages, an era of technological decline. Where the only game we have, is Dark Souls

STEP 1: ASSEMBLE BREAD INGREDIENTS
Youâ€™ll need warm water, granulated sugar, instant OR active dry yeast, salt, vegetable or canola oil and flour. Thatâ€™s it!

STEP 2: DISSOLVE THE YEAST AND ACTIVATE IT BY PROOFING
This is a simple process that takes about 5 minutes. You can see a picture below what yeast looks like when itâ€™s proofed. Itâ€™s possible to kill yeast if you use too hot of water, so aim for slightly warmer than luke-warm, or about 105Â°F. Combine warm water, yeast and 1 TBSP of the granulated sugar in your mixing bowl. Give it a quick stir and then let it sit for 5 minutes. Youâ€™ll begin to see the yeast puff up until it covers the entire surface of the water.

STEP 3: ADD REMAINING INGREDIENTS AND MIX
Add the rest of the sugar, the oil, salt and flour (You can use all-purpose flour OR bread flour!), then mix using an electric mixer until itâ€™s well combined, about 2 minutes. You can mix by hand but it will take longer.

STEP 4: KNEAD THE BREAD
You might be thinking, â€œWait! Itâ€™s already mixed!â€ Ha! Not so fast! Going through the process of kneading bread dough is crucial for bread with great texture. Kneading dough allows gluten to form which enables dough to rise better, be lighter and fluffier. you can knead by hand or with a mixer. I use the dough hook on my mixer and knead for 7 minutes. If you knead by hand, youâ€™ll want to knead for 10-11 minutes, depending on how consistent you are.

STEP 5: FIRST RISE
Place your lovely smooth, elastic bread dough in an oiled bowl and cover it with plastic wrap or a clean towel. I think plastic wrap works better because it traps hot air inside and thus, my dough requires a shorter first rise. Be sure to spray the side of the plastic wrap that will touch the dough with oil!

If your house is cool, your bread will take longer to rise. In the wintertime when my house is cooler than normal, I like to turn the oven on for 2-3 minutes, then turn it off and let the bowl of dough rise in there. The oven traps the heat for a longtime and itâ€™s the perfect atmosphere for rising dough.

STEP 6: PUNCH DOUGH AND SHAPE IT
Punching the dough down quickly releases any air pockets that have developed and helps your bread have a more consistent rise and texture. Shape your dough by rolling it gently into a ball and rolling it 2 or 3 times on the countertop so that the ball is more oblong. I usually punch down and shape the dough quickly, then place in a greased bread pan.

STEP 7: SECOND RISE
I like to do my second rise in a warm oven thatâ€™s not turned on. I turn the oven on just before I punch my dough down, then turn it off once I place the dough in the oven for the 2nd rise. Itâ€™s really only on for a minute or two, which is fine! The second rise will help shape your loaf of bread and takes about 30 minutes.

STEP 8: BAKE THE BREAD
Youâ€™re nearly there! Bread bakes for about 30-40 minutes. You know what I do to make sure my bread is perfectly cooked? I use a digital cooking thermometer! Fully cooked bread will be 190-200 degrees F. Bread recipes that include milk will need to cook until 200 degrees, but since this one doesnâ€™t, I take it out once it reaches 190 degrees. The top will be golden brown.

STEP 9: COOL THE BREAD
Cool baked bread in the pan for 10-15 minutes, then overturn pan and turn loaf out onto a cooling rack or folded towel to finish cooling. If you leave the bread in the pan for much longer than that, youâ€™ll steam it, which may cause some parts of your loaf to go soggy. No one likes soggy bread!

Left 4 Dead 2 will turn 13 years old in a few months and it's (somehow) still one of the best and most accessible co-op shooters we have.
It's easy to learn how to play, even your mom's old work laptop can run it and I'm certain most of your friends already own the game.
You can play co-op or versus with random people online (usually we have around 10k to 30k people online at all times) but playing with people you know will make the experience way better.

Left 4 Dead 2 has all the content from the first game and a bunch of extra stuff, by the way. You don't have to buy both if you want to experience everything.
I'd say the game is definitely worth the full price but it does get on sale (75~80% off) all the time.

With extensive mods to upgrade textures and lighting, provide additional character models, replace the music, add features to the menus, and more, it gets much fancier than the default install. 

I could really wish for a mod manager a la Conflict Catcher 3: toggle and save sets of mods, troubleshoot via a combination of binary search and internal database of feature interactions & common mods that may interfere with each other. Also, as seemingly low-hanging fruit, it shouldn't mark mods as "conflicting" when they have copies of the same readme.txt or other non-game file.

Would be fancy if hordes would always seem to come from somewhere. They should spawn away from the players. Currently, they can spawn in a room that was _just_ inspected by a player who's still in by the doorway and while the room has no other way in or out (doesn't have breakable walls, doors, or windows aside from the one next to the player).

Maybe a hard-mode setting so zombies are drawn to more sounds, like gunfire and speech?

Whether you like zombies, FPS titles, intense moments and challenging gameplay, you will find it all in this title. Both the first and second Left for Dead are classics and in the same way that CSGO still holds up in today's gaming scene, this easily stands up to that level of scrutiny. Game mechanics are smooth, work and the missions are straight forward in theory but special infected and hordes complicate them. Playing with friends is where this game really shines and provides so many funny, intense and butt-clenching moments that the recorded hours on steam don't do it justice as I played this for hundreds of hours on console. You can play as infected as well as survivors, you can invade other players runs as the infected and cause terror. You can solo queue, but that is a varied experience because you either get players who are speedrunning the levels or those who want to stop and fight everything and cause hordes after hordes to show up. This can be fun if you have played this game over and over, much like the individuals looking  for the chaos, but I think you are better off getting friends together for this one because the A.I. is not helpful at the best of times and as this relies on your fellow survivors looking out for you, its a major issue. But this is a brilliant zombie game and a definite recommendation from me!

This is easily my favorite game ever. 

Pros:
- Probably the best co-op game play in all of gaming; rewarding teamwork and game sense over aiming and reaction time. (Aiming and reaction time are certainly rewarded just not needed)
- Simple and responsive controls but very high skill ceiling
- Very challenging on high enough difficult but it never feels unfair
- Tons of campaigns which are (mostly) unique and well designed
- Great game play loop that stays interesting for hundreds of hours (even on single player)
- Fantastic creature design both visually and thematically
- Engaging story and unique personalities for the survivors
- Satisfying animations and sound design when killing infected
- AMAZING soundtrack
- One of the best modding communities and a built-in mod installer made by Valve
- Great game for speed running

Cons:
- Some campaigns are really bad (crash course)
- Terrible survivor AI (can be improved slightly with mods)

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

Left 4 Dead 2 is simply brilliant, especially for a game released back in 2009. Loads of content with accessible and fun zombie slaying gameplay. Full workshop support that covers every nook and cranny of the game. Charming characters and varied environments. Built on the Source engine (a positive point itself). There is just about no reason that anyone shouldn't have a gem like this in their Steam library.

Highly recommended.
Fun, but only really with friends. Doesn't do it for me one-on-one, personally. Love the characters though!

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.
a modern classic at a competitive price and crossplay support. gentle learning curve with dynamic maps and enemy placement to keep the game feeling fresh and frantic even a decade later.

Left 4 Dead is all about survival, no matter what mode you're playing. The L4D games are about staying alive, your objective is to stay alive for as long as possible. With that in mind, there is some general advice that will help you through any situation:
1. Always keep moving. A standing target is an easy one to hit.
2. Work together with all 3 teammates - never go off alone.
3. Conserve ammo and supplies, only using when necessary.

Bought this game due to attention brought up in Back 4 Blood's launch and I'm happy to report that most of the aspects in this game have aged to perfection just as others say! -I fell for this game quick along with a majority of the vast communities that revolve around it. Note that for 1) The versus mode can be a little bit toxic as expected on a 10 year old game and that 2) I have yet to play Back 4 Blood so I can't really compare the projects myself. Anyways for the price point, the amount of content offered from the community and versus is huge!! -It's no wonder players can rack up as many as 1000 to 5000!! hours from this experience as it's just that fun and that replayable! So buy this game on sale or on the store page right now -I really don't care as it's very generously priced and have already purchased this game for many of my online friends

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

If you don't want to read everything: I personally loved this game. It was really fun to play with friends, the mechanics are fun to play with, and all the gamemodes are great to try out. Overall a great game despite it's age.

Honestly I'm not much of a fan of shooter games in general, but L4D2 (and L4D) surprised me with how good it was. For me, the teamwork aspect of the game is great. Working with others to complete the objective properly, and also to warn others of special zombies that might be around, is just a great feeling in my opinion. Although this game is quite old, it still holds up quite well as both a standalone game, and a game to play with friends. I recommend playing through the campaign, and to also try out all the other gamemodes too.

I am a 54-year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing Left 4 Dead 2. 
I am a single father to my son, who is now 14. My son recently started playing  Left 4 Dead 2. 
In less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. 
This was terrible for me because it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son 
because he was always out with his friends or watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam 
account to play with my son. I started playing, but this was my first time playing a video game
 since the 90's, so I was quite lost. I asked my son for help, and together we spent some hours playing Left 4 Dead 2. 
I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my son since my wife had died. Playing video games 
reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought 
me and my son closer again, and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well.

13 years later, no other game has topped this on what it does.  Closest would be Vermintide, though that one focuses more and fantasy and melee.  
This game is timeless.  The mods, the gameplay, the characters, the memes, and just the general fun of it all.  It's still a simple game.  A gauntlet through hordes of zombies to get from A to B.  A simple concept that works so well.  One that has stood the test of time.  I'm surprised not enough games try to follow this simple concept, with very few exceptions.  Sure the graphics aren't as great as games today, even back then it was simply acceptable.  But that's the thing about source games.  They're good enough.  You'll always find yourself replaying this from time to time.  You'll always go through the workshop to tweak the game to your very liking.  Like I said, timeless.  I'm afraid, if they ever make a Left 4 Dead 3, it won't be as great as this.  Here's to another decade.

I grew up on L4D and L4D2 expands on fun concepts and fun characters in a way that is engaging but not overcomplicated. Though I much prefer the first game because of nostalgic bias, the second game adds plenty to make it stand out on its own. The new zombie classes are more of a mixed bag (Jockeys are more mind numbingly annoying than actual problems, while Spitters if used correctly in the Versus mode can change the tide of the entire game) but the new areas are done well and the characters are written charmingly. Get this version if you want to play both games, get the original L4D if you want the full nostalgia factor, but overall L4D2 is a good game without being too far into or out of the shadow of its predecessor.

gran bought it for me Christmas 2009. I was 9 years old and played it on my parents PC at the time. I was terrible at it and didn't play it often because I was absolutely terrified of it. That night I couldn't sleep at all and thought everything that moved  was a zombie. My family reassured me that there were no zombies and that if any broke in we had a shotgun so we would be safe. My family then put it near their bed and went to sleep to show me it was close by if anything happened. Later I still couldn't sleep so I went into their room and took the shotgun so i would feel safer. As I got back into bed with it in my hands my gran must've heard a noise so she came into my room. I got such a fright that I blew her brains out with my shotgun thinking she was a zombie. My parents ran in and saw the horror of my gran sitting there. I have never played the game since. RIP granny 1700-2009

Left 4 Dead 2 is a prime example of a true classic. It holds up today and it will hold up in the future. The same can be said about Valve's past titles. I bought this at least over a dozen times over the years and I don't regret any money spent. Endless fun, tops replayability loop, memorable characters and mods give so much. If you've never played $10 is easily worth it. The fact that I get so much more out of this game over a fully priced $60-$70 one today speaks volumes. 

So where the FUCK is Left 4 Dead 3? With Half-Life: Alyx I pray we see more VR games from Valve in the near future and I HOPE it's L4D3. I'd buy a headset instantly in such a scenario. At this rate however, I doubt we'll see it. Can't have high hopes.

Oh man, a review! Hoho, boy do I have one for y'all. Hey, I ever tell you about this one time my buddy Keith and I popped open a couple of beers and was playin' Swamp Fever Chapter 2? Yeaah......turns out- map is a reaaaaallllll piece of shit. Like some Mexican dude was on our team right? This dude. I mean, ho man! Not to get rude or anything, 'cause that's like bad karma and stuff- he wasn't the brightest tool in the box. Yeah, he wasn't going around settin' any world records or nothin', 'cept maybe bein' the world's dumbest teammate! Heheh, anyway, we were crossin' mud and bones to get to this giant jet plane that crashed like a couple of days ago and all of a sudden we hear this big dude in the distance...and when I saw him, I swear on MY LIFE MAN, this thing couldn't be less than the size of a truck! Man, Keith and I, we were mowin' down this guy with our rifles kind of like the movies, you know, and as we were doin' it, the Mexican dude rivera47302... pulled out our ONLY molotov and threw it at that son of a bitch! Now, I ain't no chemist but this map has all this water and stuff and that's just bad news for fire, you know? So Keith thought'd he try startin' a votekick to boot that guy off our team, but he totally left! And right as he was in the menu- I get SMOKED, yeah, and my buddy Keith gets humped on by this little dude! And the AI? Didn't even help or nothin', she just walked straight into the big dude like she was gonna kiss him on the lips! Haha!!! Accordin' to Keith, that was the worst time of his life. Ho man, at first it was funny, then it got sad, but then it got funny again...ho man....

Personally, I consider Left 4 Dead 2 as the best party FPS to play with fun and delight. The base aim of the game is pretty basic: survival and rescue from the zombie hell. In addition, there are a lot of game modes make you not get bored for hundreds or even thousands of hours. Still one of the best multiplayer survival.

This game is just one of the classics, man. And when I first picked it up, it really stood out to me because even at the time of it's release, (somehow it's gotten worse) there were soo many awful zombie survival games that were coming out and this game was really just a dime in the rough. The only problem I had was how quickly it released after the first but nevertheless, it stuck with me as a masterpiece. I love all of the characters and their individual little quirks. The gameplay is so utterly smooth and thanks to the director, it always fits your style and skill. The gore and gibbing physics in this game are so brutal and satisfying that I usually need a change of pants once I'm done playing. The score for this game is phenomenal and every sound effect fits perfectly. The multiplayer and co-op aspect of this game are so beautiful and are the #1 reason to come back for more to me. I mean there is nothing better than just getting three of your buddies and yourself to play the campaign with each other and just have a good laugh/time. Certain parts of this game can be a little icky, the main thing that sticks out to me is the AI companions if you're playing single-player, they're never helpful enough to ever want them over a real player. Another thing is sometimes the level design can be a little to linear, and I mean it is rare but sometimes it occurs that your in a very slim place and you're getting absolutely destroyed and you just feel cheated. And on the flip side a few time the level design can be too expansive and open and leave you confused, lost, or even bored, but that's also rare occurances. This has to be my top game to sit down and play while listening to slow, sludgy as fuck heavy metal and is really a childhood game to me that I grew up loving and still do.

In short, it's an easy playing game that does not get boring. Enemies spawn and come from different locations every time, even if playing the same level, and there are always more than you think which keeps you on your toes. Missions aren't incredibly long and offer neat maps to explore. Also, the Witch and similar enemies are a cool addition which make you slow down and plan when facing them.

Plus, there is tons of aftermarket content to download from Steam (Dimmsdale Dimmadome hat, for example) and there are some fun maps to grab as well.

 One thing: Survival is incredibly tough. Be prepared.

This game is so bloody (literally) good to play with friends, even when solo you can have a blast by playing with the AI or even with the crazy mods, in what other shooter game can Jack Cooper from Titanfall 2 fight a buff Minecraft Steve with a comically large spoon while Payday 2 music plays?

The characters are fun and memorable, and the amount of unique dialogue keeps me coming back to see what funny stuff they say next. The campaigns that have changes in the layout are the best, like Dark Carnival and Dead Centre. Let's not forget those infected, from the Smoker to the Tank these dead bozos ooze with not only character, but also mystery fluids I dare not touch with a barge pole.

â€œI am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.â€

Left 4 Dead 2 is a game that likes to shoot fast and loose from the hip. Its feels frantic and wildly unrefined - as a new player its likely you'll find yourself shooting erratically in to a crowd of zombies and hitting nothing except your teammates. And they'll hate you for it - but you'll have fun nonetheless.

Left 4 Dead 2 Is possibly the MOST immersive zombie game I've ever seen, I mean the attention to detail within the timeline that it was made is honestly insane! now it's not as immersive as your tell tale walking dead, or resident evil, but it's definitely fast placed, and wildly fun with friends. This game is defiently worth your attention! I felt really big satisfaction while I was playing this with my frineds. Action, zombies, blood, shooting â€“ everything in here! If you want to spend your time playing with your friends and having fun â€“ this game will be one of the greatest picks.

This game saved my life.

I am 43.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game for forty minutes.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

Now I've played this first person apocalypse survival shooter when it first came out on the Xbox 360, and it is still a very fun game to play especially with multiple people! I cannot tell you how many times I've been jump scared by a horde of infected even when I knew it was coming. Don't even get me started on the soundtrack, it gives this tense feeling that you could be attacked at any second from anywhere. The voice lines from each character is amazing, from them introducing themselves to quick banter/down time chats between each other during the campaign. I would definitely recommend this game to someone who wants to play a first person type of game that involves zombies!
This game just never dies. GOAT zombie shooter game 100000/10.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

This game stands the test of time, it wasn't until Back 4 Blood released that I realized all the subtle ways Left 4 Dead 2 makes you more immersed within it's world.

The characters are dynamic. A lot of the environment is destructible. The music is client side and changes depending on what is currently happening. Zombies are damaged in unique ways given how and where you attack them.

Left 4 Dead 2 is a masterpiece that STILL reigns as the must-have-staple of the zombie genre. It's a classic for a reason.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who has passed away. My son got this game for Christmas in 2013 from his mother, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 0.2 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and realized how dogshit he is. I asked my Son to unistall this game as his last family member wishes. I loved watching him be complete dogshit at the game. This game has ever since brought me and my son distant again and now we actually spend time not looking at each other again. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought me, (my sons last family member) many joyful times.

This Game Right Here, Is A Flawless Masterpiece, Im Gonna Describe Everything It Does Right And What It Improved.

Improvements

1 - In L4D1 They Didn't Have Gibs Good Enough To Make Actual Realistic, Fun And Satisfying Experience While Killing Zombies, So They Added Red Mist Only And Just A Little Bit Of Gibs From Explosions Not As Much As The Sequel, In The Meantime L4D2 Improves It.

2 - L4D1 Makes The Special Infected Look A Bit More Casual, L4D2 Adds More Details And Decaying To Them. Example : L4D1's Smoker Has Less Blisters On His Face And His Clothes Look More Casual And Cleaner Like The Jacket Looking Considerably And Noticeably Green, While L4D2 Gives Him A More Decaying Look, More Blisters And A Bigger One At That, And They Remove The Jacket And Make The Shirt Have A Decaying Look And Feel To It And Has Dried Blood All Over It And Is Shredded, Similar To What They Did To The Hunter, In L4D1 He Had On His Arms Tape But Then In L4D2 He Now Has Barely Any Tape And More Decaying Skin And Little Blisters.

3 - L4D2 Adds 3 More Special Infected : The Charger, The Jockey And The Spitter
The Jockey Helps Taking Other Survivors To A Hunter/Charger/Smoker Or Even A Witch
The Spitter Is Similar To The Boomer But Instead Of Bile/Puke Its Acid Which Instead Leading Zombies It Creates Acid That Injures The Survivor And When Dead, Has Acid Coming Out, And May Even Serve As A Quicker Kill Like When A Hunter Is On A Survivor The Spitter Spits At The Survivor Taking Extra Damage And A Faster Death.

The Charger Can Charge Onto Others, Hence The Name, Hes Useful For Charging Others Out Of Windows Or Places That When Survivors Fall Into, They Die, Similar To The Windows Or Balconies In Dead Center, And Swamp Fever's Deep Lakes, Including No Mercy's Deep Water Or Buildings.

The Good Things :
They Punish You For Going Away From The Team, Because Special Infected Have A Much Bigger Advantage Similar How A Hunter Finishes His Time On A Survivor Who Abandons The Others, If One Latches Onto You You Cannot Take Him Out, Similar To Smokers And Chargers Spitters Also Help To Kill You Faster.

Sometimes The Team Have To Sacrifice Someone To Continue On.

And Final But Not Least, There Are Certain Things You Use To Get Yourself Out Of A Life Or Death Situation 

1 - Being Able To Slash The Tongue Of The Smoker Pulling You With A Melee Weapon Before Being Dragged Onto The Ground.

2 - Being Able To Kick A Hunter In The Process Of Jumping On You Before It Latches Onto You (Can Also Work With Jockeys But Their Faster, Better Reaction Time Is Needed),

3 - Kicking A Boomer Away From You Before It Pukes And Shooting It While It Doesn't Explode Near You Too.

(Those Are The Only Things I Know About  Avoiding Life Or Death Situations, There May Even Be Alot More I Missed).

Bonus : Comparison

L4D2 Has A Much More Stabilized And Optimized And Satisfying Experience, And Most Maps Take Part In Day Time And Is More Strategic With More Expansive Ways For Special Infected To Hide
L4D1 Offers A Horror Experience That Actually Does A Good Job On Jump scaring Players From Dark Places
And Most Of The Maps Are During Nighttime

And The Maps And Textures Have Lots Of Details And Past And Future Comparisons.
A lot of fun especially with friends.

Amazing game, completely filled with nostalgia. Definitely the best zombie game on the market. My only complaint are add-ons automatically re-enabling themselves on launch.

from the first game, to the second, i've been a fan since age seven; my heart full for the blood and guts, the horror, the guns, etc. all up my alleyway. i've loved l4d2 for as long as i can remember; and i cannot see myself growing tired of this game for many years to come. the amount of times you can replay it, find easter eggs, new knacks, tricks and such, brings out the little things, making this game fun. i've made the most beautiful memories and have had the most memorable times in my life, just through this game. it's dear to my heart. 

the graphics aren't bad at all for a 2008 game. there's some kind of charm to l4d2, whether it be the well-done soundtracks, campaigns, survival and versus gameplay; i continue to find joy in getting on and playing a match or two. i've met so many cool people here. the fan base is insane, and i've genuinely enjoyed the interactions i've had (aside from the griefers, but to be expected). the workshops are by far my favorite, which add little tinkerings and such to the game, which make it even better than before. so much talent displayed through these items.
please do get ahold of the general basics of the game. play through all the maps, grow familiar with them. there are so many people who play, and do not understand much, and ultimately, suck balls just w/o trying. especially on versus maps, if anything. at least have enough skill, and gradually get better at the game. it is cheap, and allows so much, provides quite a bit. l4d2 is still such a competitive game, and holds value to most who play on the regular. 

honestly, i do recommend this game for any zombie apocalypse enthusiasts, who enjoy first person shooter games, with the ability to play online, with friends; and of course, if they aren't extremely heavy on spectacular graphics. the gameplay makes up for all of that, and the memories made are for a lifetime. take a spin, and see how it makes you feel. :3 <3

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Whether you play for 20 min or 20 hours at a stretch. L4D2 is amazing. So much fun, adrenaline and monster annihilation. It actually has a bit of a "per chapter story" and you want to help the characters survive, not only playing with friends (which is excellent!) but on your own. Even though my account indicates only 28.2 hours of play I have played much more offline in a single player campaign mode. It is the epitome of a zombie/monster game. Quick if you like, or take your time. But beware, if you take too long to explore, they will come for you. Relentless, screaming, disturbing hordes of flesh ripping, in your face demons. What more could you want?!

Hello and thank you for taking the time to read this review. My thoughts and my view do not represent or dictate anyone else's view but my own. I purchased this game recently in an attempt to believe that I was going to have fun and enjoy the game. However I have come to learn as I have played the game that the monsters and zombies that are in the game are completely unrealistic they have rigorous health and that the physics and the Dynamics and the reality of the game is complete b*******. the zombies in this game can kill you with one hit or they can knock you down either way but yet if you have a semi automatic gun or a 50 caliber rifle and you shoot one of the zombies or the charger or the tank nothing happens it just like nothing. I understand when developers won't to make a game and they create a game for enjoyment and content purposes but there has to be an equal chance for both player as well as the game itself. Let me put it this way and I'm going to say this very frankly. My 4 year old son would rather go outside and eat dirt rather than play this game. my grandmother would rather experience death than play this game. My dog would have more enjoyment licking his own ass than playing this game. the best thing that the developers can do for this game is just a simply take it off the steam Workshop because it is not enjoyable, it is very unrealistic, there is no equal balance between player and game. And it is horribly made

One of the last and few good co-op shooters to not rely on player progression or RPG systems. There's no unlockables, no carrots on sticks. It's all about simple joys, short term goals, and your own mastery over the game. You simply choose a campaign/gamemode and hit the ground running.

On the flip side... the game is plagued by many annoying mechanics, exploits, mouth-breathing bot AI, and one of the worst pub experiences of any game. That being said, you can mitigate most of these issues by playing with friends and/or using mods.

There was a time when zombie fatigue and 100+ hours had me loathing L4D, but after seeing so many other co-op games come and go, I've come to appreciate this one's remarkable staying power.

As in the style of any other average steam review of being super vague, this is a pretty fun game. Everyone's experience is different depending on what add-ons are used. In my playthrough, you get to play as Big Smoke, Woody, Pepsi-Man, and ENA. You have to fight your way through waves of Minecraft zombies while also looking out for such enemies as Gaston, Sandy Cheeks, Asui Tsuyu, Wario, some dragon loli, and the Nostalgia Critic. These main enemies will hinder your progress, but isn't too overwhelming and causes some short but intense games. Beware of two other special enemies, Terry Crews who throws old spice rocks at you, and a bitch who claws you to death. Overall definitely worth the $10

This game came out 13 years ago as i'm typing this and its still one of the best zombie games of all time. Whenever i play a first person shooter like battlefield, call of duty, insurgency sandstorm, team fortress 2, counter strike, etc... It always felt to me like i was never working or supporting my teammates, like everyone in the lobby was playing as a individual running around doing their own thing. This also applied to me when i played battle royals because the most amount of teamwork your going to do is revive someone and make call outs.But left for dead was special, because the game was DESIGNED around teamwork. Sharing your healing supplies, reviving your teammates, getting saved from  special infected,  protecting your teammate who got boomed, and that's just the start! Ironically "left for dead" is one of the best examples of a team based game. Sure, maybe a 3000 hour player can bunny hop his way through every map without taking any damage all by himself but most players are going to have to stick together to survive because of the mechanics turtle rock studios and valve have implemented.

Now just from that left for dead 2 would be a good game but there is a reason why people can put so many hours into the game and still enjoy it and that is because of the director. the director is a AI that controls the zombies, health and ammo pickups, and can make changes to the map based on the current situation, status, location and skill of each player. For example lets say that you play the same map twice with the different players. The first team you played with are good so the AI director spawns more zombies and less medical supplies. But on second play through you get stuck with bad players. so The AI does the opposite, it spawns in less zombies and more meds. This is just a simple example but there are so many things and variables that this AI can change that playing the same map over and over again will still have a new experience to enjoy. 

Now just from that left for dead 2 would be a great game BUT WAIT THEIRS MORE! Special infected are zombies that have become mutated and now have special ability's. These zombies have became the corner stone of the left for dead franchise because they are the biggest factor to why players need to stick together. There are 8 unique special infected all with their own unique ability's. 4 of them are what i call "Pinners". They are named hunter, smoker, charger, and jockey and if they successfully pin you ( GET IT?????) you wont be able to escape without your teams help. There are 2 support infected, the boomer is a bloated zombie that throws up on its victim (doesn't that sound nice?). You will have impaired vision and a horde of zombies will spawn and come for you. The spitter stomach spits acid that can be used as area denial or help do more damage on a pinned survivor. and finally there are the 2 boss zombies, the tank and the witch. The tank is a big hunk of meat that has a large amount of health and does a lot of damage with his ranged attack  (literally grabbing the concrete off the ground and throwing it at you) and his melee (bitch slapping you so hard you propel 20 feet). And finally the last special infected: the witch, she wont attack you unless provoked and can be avoided entirely, if she is startled however she will rush after the person who startled her, unless she is killed she will one shot them to incapacitation or death depending on the difficulty.

left for dead 2 would be a amazing game already BUT NO THEIRS MORE.
The writing, the map design, the character design, and the small details adds so much personality to this game. There are 8 playable survivors that you will quickly learn to love, their names are Bill, Zoey, Francis, Louis, Coach, Rochelle, Ellis, and Nick and each one of them is unique because their of their character design, voice, personality, and their own animations. Simply asking multiple players their favorite character will bring varied answer due to the amazing writing,voice acting, and designs of each character. Just trust me when I say that their dialogue can bring a smile to your face. The maps are vastly different from one another ranging from a carnival to a airport, a hospital to a swamp, a large city to a flooded town. each map brings a new atmosphere and they are all masterfully design for human and zombie players to enjoy. there is also another director, the music director, it will play music depending on the situation that you are in, so if your fighting a big horde of zombies you will have intense music playing. if a special infected spawns they will have their own unique music cue,and if a tank spawns in you will hear its distinctive music track.

And with that should explain why- THEIRS STILL MORE, JUST ONE MORE PARAGRAPH I PROMISE.
Besides the main campaign there are multiple side modes in the game, but I'm going to be brief for their are a bunch of side modes and i don't want to stretch this review any farther so i will only talk about the most popular ones. There is survival where you survive as long as you can in a small part of a map. Mutations where you can choose between a bunch of random special modes such as having only tanks spawn in or having a rocket jumping grenade launcher. and the most popular side mode where i put most of my hours in is versus mode, a 4 vs 4 mode  where one team tries to get as many points as they can in a chapter while the other team stops them by playing as special infected and try's to kill them. after the round ends the teams will switch sides and after that round is over it will go to the next chapter till the end.their is also the community workshop where you can download mods that can change character models, add more maps, change weapons, and much, much more.

Now this game is a masterpiece don't get me wrong but i do have a few nitpicks with it. There are still small bugs that you can find,the game does not get nearly enough updates as it used to. the player base is what I describe as a bunch of angry, edgy, lonely, and horny teens being as toxic as they possible can be. And lastly the game can lag a lot depending on the host of the lobby. And that's it, that's all of the nitpicks i can think of for a 13 YEAR OLD GAME.

with all of this in mind, that is why left for dead 2 is such a masterpiece.

thanks for reading.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.
Many years later it's still one of the best fps zombie game I've ever played, a classic game that still holds great quality and replay-ability.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Where do i even begin, this game is and will continue to be my favourite game of all time, been playing since the Xbox 360 days.

Gameplay: F*cking brilliant, the game is based around teamwork, the special infected are designed to punish bad teamplayers. Think its an okay idea to run off on your own? Nope. game will spawn a hunter to pounce on you and rip your guts out. this teaches new players. "Oh maybe i should stay with my team so the hunter doesn't kill me."

Sound and music: Most multiplayer games don't have music because it tends to "get in the way" but L4D2's music helps you know whats coming and heightens the horror experience, all the special infected have their unique sounds and music themes for when they have spawned, idling and attacking. For new players hearing a Jockey's maniacal laughter or the Boomer's deep gurgling of vomit will make those cheeks clench. Hell, i still get uneasy when i hear the Charger violently muttering to himself.

Characters: Don't get me started on the characters we'll be here forever. All i'll say is these 8 legends still make me laugh to this day.
"Ugh what's that smell?"
"All i smell is ribs."
"Because all you you think about is ribs Coach!"

Theme: The original L4D's theme was "We are f*cked but we'll keep going" but this one is more "F*ck yeah kill zombies".

Its full of stuff that you miss if you ignore all of the games lore which is fine i understand most people are not playing this for story and talking about the story, its nothing special but still good with amazing world building (At the beginning you have C.E.D.A's lacklaster response to the outbreak and the end where you have the military's cold but needed bombing of New Orleans) the games not depression fuel but its not a full out comedy.

The community is (99% of the time) super friendly, ive met so many awesome people because of this game.

even if you somehow get bored of the game there is a thriving workshop full of amazing items. Stupid items and amazing stupid items.

Just buy it, it goes 3aud on sales.
