When I first sat down to play muck I was expecting a bad free to play meme game. And what I got, was a New, Unique, and frankly Breathtaking take on the survival genre. This game is incredibly nuanced, with an extraordinarily deep, Intelligent, yet still challenging story, that will play with your emotions at every turn.

What this game feels like, is as if you gave an expert team of developers an infinite budget, and no time constraints, and told them to make what they want. Further, the graphics that this game provides are some of the best looking, realistic graphics that I've ever seen come from a video game, and it manages to keep My PC cold while doing so.

This game has one of the most intense, and rich story's out there, good enough to rival the likes of RdR2, the entire persona series, the kingdom hearts games, and much more. And with doing all of this, the game is still able to make downright genius social commentary on many real world issues. but not so much that it hampers the story in any way.

To play this game for free, truly is a blessing, Anyone who is out for money knows they could make millions off of this tremendous piece of art. and while, maybe we cant pay for this modern Picasso we can support the creator in other ways

Left 4 Dead 2 is still to this day the best cooperative shooter I have ever played since I first started it on my Xbox 360. Anytime my friends and I want to play a game together, I can always rely on this game to provide hours of fun and engagement. The game from start to finish in almost every campaign feels like (and sometimes literally is) a well-paced roller coaster of high-action zombie evisceration and careful scavenging for supplies to make it through the horde, and to the exit door.

The Steam release of Left 4 Dead 2 includes all DLC, as well as all of the original Left 4 Dead's campaigns. The game is packed with infinitely replayable content that is aided even further by the campaign levels' dynamic nature, which can create different routes and thus different strategies each playthrough. The main factor in Left 4 Dead 2's replayability however is the in-game Director, which alters the game as you play according to how you play. This includes sending a zombie horde during a period of extended rest, or placing more health packs throughout the level if your team is particularly injured.

The Southern United States setting of Left 4 Dead 2 lends it to more visually distinct and sunny environments than the generally moody and dark levels of the original Left 4 Dead. The classic zombie shopping mall scenario, a clown zombie infested carnival, and the streets of a waterfront city particularly stand out. The same character archetypes from the original Left 4 Dead return, but applied to entirely new character designs and backgrounds. The leader Coach, the optimist mechanic Ellis, the pessimist conman Nick, and the caring producer Rochelle are memorable characters that players will grow to love over time.

While the overall population of the online multiplayer has declined in the many years since the game's release, it is still possible to find online lobbies in both cooperative and versus play. Online versus provides an experience entirely different from usual gameplay, placing players in the decrepit shoes of one of the special infected enemies to stop the survivor team from reaching the exit. There are 6 special infected in total excluding the Tank and Witch, and each has its own unique purpose and synergizes with the other special infected to create excellent team play. These special infected are of course encountered in singleplayer and co-op as well and act as the main threats among the sea of common infected, providing variety to a level's encounters. There is often a Tank in each level that acts as a boss enemy, and its behavior is as its name suggests; barreling down corridors towards the survivors and smashing anything in its path with a large health pool to boot.

I can confidently recommend Left 4 Dead 2 to anyone, it's hard not to enjoy this game. Left 4 Dead 2 often goes on sale for dirt cheap so if $10 seems too steep for you, you can very well wait a bit for it to drop as low as $2. In my opinion this is a must-play.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Left 4 Dead 2 is the perfect 2009 zombie shooter, and none are yet to surpass it.
It's travel based, so no camping or arbitrary collect X fungus for the hut man. The environments are detailed and the director can spawn even laser sights just outside of where you'd look, so look hard, but also go fast because hordes and specials... it's a great blend of pacing and the Director assists that intent.

7/8 characters still hold strong to this very day, 13 years later.
The special infected design has been the icon for special horde enemy design - AVP, "this one is like the Hunter" - WWZ, "This one is like the Hunter / Charger" - Vermintide, "this one is like the Jockey" - and so on. The detail in their cosmetic designs still impresses and hints even years later, and their AI behaviour is harrowing considering the in-world apocalyptic scenario, with intelligent yet maliciously feral special infected stalking survivors and waiting behind corners.

The modding capability is the pinnacle of workshop support, but of course it attracts weebshit.

It's been one of the only games ever that has been worth the damn money. Screw that 60 dollar AAA 8 hour playthrough with no replayability, I don't give a shit about the graphics, 2009 source is all you need to make a game able to be read. I don't need 30 ridges and lines per polygon, I need to be able to distinguish what I'm looking at and not have a trillion particle effects and ability countdowns cluttering my screen.
But surprise surprise, all you need to make a game last is make it good. l4d2 has no meta progression, at all. No levels, no unlocks, no perks, no skills, no active abilities, no loadout presets. Just your skills and the luck of the drop. As such, it leaves even new players able to match a skilled one. After all, shoot gun into swarm coming through door. Nobody has an advantage just because they have multitudes more free time and got a big number, the advantage is skill. As such, whenever something happens, it's not because you didn't have reload speed 2, or shove stamina 3. It's because you need to manage limited resources. Only ammo is infinite, but bullets only hurt, every scratch counts. There's no 'press E to healing aura' bollocks.
Every attempted evolution of L4D2 has missed points of it. No meta progression, don't have dozens and dozens of guns, don't have 5 attachment slots, don't make infected be true bullet sponges, don't have a bazillion things to do, don't make the graphics an overdetailed mishmash.
It's disappointing, because we probably just... won't ever get another L4D, with maybe another new infected, more official detailed and ambiently horrific maps, another gun or two, a fourth throwable... But L4D2 is still playable, and it's amazingly bereft of bugs and glitches.

Left 4 Dead 2. What can I say that hasn't already been said about this game. Even after 13 years [ at the time of this review ] The community is going strong and still is played to the point where it is one of the top played games on steam, and for good reason. Left 4 Dead 2 takes 4 players [friends, online, or bots] and has them attempt to get from point A to point B to safely extract from the Zombie Apocalypse. There are loads of maps, weapons, infected zombies, and story [though not traditional story telling more from character dialog and writings throughout the map and safe room]. There is also a multiplayer option that allows for gameplay for both survivors and infected. I wish that Value would understand that the fanbase is DESPERATELY wanting a Left 4 Dead 3 [No Back 4 Blood is not a good day and is not Left 4 Dead 3 in anyway. ] If you somehow have not played this game, Please check it out! Especially with friends.

Left for dead 2 
One of the greatest video games of our generation maybe even of all time. To experience such luxury for a fraction of what it's worth is absolutely astounding,brilliant,superb,astonishing,incredible,enlightening and pleasant. 
To gracefully slaughter the undead hordes, Is such a delight. No such elegance can be found in any media or activity. There is no saying how creative and charming the cast of characters are, truly the peak of human psychoanalysis on how to construct an array of characters. Ranging from a Hillbilly who's (questionably homosexual) to a scam artist who enjoys the pleasures of life such as making fun of the hillbilly and his companions.
It is not without saying the unique aspects of this game stem not from it's idea but from it's execute as the creative choice to implement original designs of the zombies which reside in this masterpiece and give them special traits which spice up the gameplay and make it 100 times more extravagant and enjoyable. 
It is safe to say and see that the game which you hope to purchase is without any question or doubt a MASTERPIECE.

I admit, I like Left 4 Dead 2, it's a great game, and I will put some information on [i] why [/i].

First of all, we gotta go over the positives.

What does the game bring to the table?
[hr][/hr]
First of all, it brings a lot of good mechanics, the zombies are a big threat by themselves already (At least, if you play Advanced and Expert, and of course Expert Realism), but with the Special Infected, this brings an unique flavor to the game. Also, there's a MASSIVE workshop, if you get through all these anime-style thingies, a lot of decent stuff exists, I might even make a collecton the "good stuff" of the workshop.
The weapon selection is pretty fine and dandy, and the achievement stats are a pretty unique thing, as I don't recall seeing something like that in, for example, CS:GO or TF2.
I also must admit that I love the characters. I've got no favorite, but all these characters, Ellis, Coach, Bill, Francis, and even Rochelle and Zoey, all have some sort of character and personality, but also more things that define them. It's not typical clichÃ© characters that were made in a day or two, they have [i] a story behind them. [/i]

What do I think is bad?
[hr][/hr]
Well, first of all, the AI Director is [b] not [/b] a bad idea in my opinion, it keeps the game slightly unique, but only slightly, and this is where I want to bring some criticism: The game feels the same a lot of the time, like, the Director doesn't have any unique strategies or something like that, the algorythm only looks at how well you're doing, and my suggestions for this are following, even if it's difficult to do:
-Track player movements, are they going the same path as most players go? If they do not, they are somewhat rewarded with slightly easier gameplay and, over time, a slightly more balanced experience.
-Give the Director concrete, randomized plans that go with the flow of the algorythm, like, will he bring a specific sortiment a lot, or just a lot of commons instead of Specials? Will he try to pressure the players into a corner and then spawn a lot of Spitters? Will he rely on tanks more than hordes? You know, concrete plans that are sort of randomized, but also a collection of randomized ideas and tactics, to make much more gameplay that you can't easily predict, this may piss off people in Versus, but there could always be adjustments depending on the gamemode.
-Look at the players' weapon selection, if they have a lot of snipers, there will be Infected that can be easily hit by a Sniper, but also spawn, for example, a Smoker as a counter to that, or Hunters. This may be a thing already, but I'd really like that.
I don't know other negatives, the Director is just underwhelming to me.

I would say, with all these things, I must give the game a 8-9/10. The worst part is probably the lack of variance with the Director, but other than that, for a 2009 game, it hold itself up to a good standard very well.
I may just be new, salty, or stupid, but in my 27 hours of this, I think the game's good and fine, just please make the Director better, alright?

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

[h3][b][u]Short Answer:[/u][/b][/h3] One of the best zombie games, co-op games, and FPS games on the PC. Packed with content that can easily be played for hundreds of hours, but also supports Steam Workshop mods should the base game ever get stale. Play it alone or play it with friends, but avoid the decade-old toxicity of the online community.

[h3][b][u]Long Answer:[/u][/b][/h3] [i]Left 4 Dead 2[/i] is a co-operative first-person shooter in which you and your friends play as a group of survivors as they fight their way through countless hordes of humans infected by a zombie virus. It's a game that I'd argue needs no introduction, being almost as old as the distribution service on which it sits, yet still maintaining a concurrent player count that has almost never fallen below five figures in its 13-year long history. It's one of the most well-known and well-beloved games on this platform, and it even holds the title of my first ever Steam purchase all the way back in November 2009. All of this is to say that [i]Left 4 Dead 2[/i] was, and still is, an amazing game.

The core gameplay revolves around navigating a mostly-linear map alongside your teammates in order to reach a safe house on the other side, doing a bit of exploring along the way to find new gear and prepare for the harder battles ahead. Most of the enemies you fight are simple "common infected"--weak on their own, dangerous in a group--but sprinkled in each map are a variety of "special infected", each with unique abilities and a high capacity to harm you and your team if you're not careful. The variety and quantity of infected you fight changes with every playthrough, and it's all thanks to one of game's most interesting features: the AI Director, a system running in the background that alters things like enemy/item spawn rate and even level layout depending on player performance. Maybe it'll spawn multiple special infected at the same time if you're clearing a level too easily, or put some extra healing items in your path if you're starting to struggle, or ambush players that stray too far from their teammates. Much of the overall design ensures that [b]cooperation is always necessary, and every player regardless of skill level is a valuable part of the team[/b]; conversely, it also ensures that players who abandon or neglect their team will be swiftly punished by the Director for doing so.

The Director's automatic balancing combined with (mostly) competent AI teammates make it so that, [b]despite its co-op focus, it's still enjoyable even if you're playing solo[/b]. If anything, playing solo is arguably a better way to learn how to play, as it's easier to figure things out when you're not getting distracted or rushed along by other players. That being said, [b]the game as a whole is a lot more fun with friends[/b]. Whether it's just you and a buddy against the horde in Co-op or an eight-person party competing against each other in Versus, every campaign you play will be an absolute blast--just as long as you make sure your lobbies are set to "friends only" (more on that later).

The base game already contained enough replayable content to last a long time, but updates over the years have added even more game modes and levels to the mix, including updated versions of all the original [i]Left 4 Dead[/i] campaigns and some new ones that tie the story of the two games together. Should all of this start to become repetitive, [b]look no further than the Steam Workshop to breathe new life into the game[/b]. Though many of the most popular mods are just funny texture/sound swap-outs, there are also a lot of new campaigns and game modes to be found that can really shake things up. One of my recent favorites is [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=121070254]Rayman1103's Mutation Mod[/url], consisting of a ton of new modes that tweak the standard game rules in order to make things more challenging or just more entertaining. It has modes for everything from solo to Co-op to Versus, but you're gonna want a guide like [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=536442883]this one[/url] on hand since the menus lack proper descriptions of each mode.

I can only think of two things that I'd consider a point of concern before making a purchase--one I found in my recent return to the game, and one that's been the subject of serious criticism from players over the years:
[olist]
[*][b]There's no real tutorial to be found in the base game[/b]. You're occasionally given on-screen prompts explaining the basic mechanics, but for the most part you're just thrown right into the action and left to figure everything out on your own. You don't get a lot of time to get your bearings, especially thanks to the Director throwing threats at you if you spend too long loitering around; and if you're playing with people above your skill level, you're going to find yourself struggling to keep up. Luckily, shortly before writing this, a member of the community named Kyle H. McCloud created an [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2800506083]unofficial tutorial campaign[/url], and I can't overstate how helpful it is. You're given a safe environment to test every piece of gear, core mechanic, and special infected fight, and it's filled with detailed information that even I never knew before. It's a must-have for any player jumping into this game for the first time.

[*]This is something that can't really be fixed, but it can be avoided: for many years, the game has been plagued by a toxic community that makes online play borderline impossible for casual players. Almost every constructive negative review I could find highlights this issue, and I'll let those regale you with the horror stories of elitist players, the abuse of the "kick player" function, and other generally bad behavior. I'll just leave it at this: [b]if you're going to get this game, play singleplayer or in a friends-only lobby--do [i]not[/i] go in with the expectation of playing with randoms online[/b].
[/olist]

I played a lot of this game in the first couple years of its release, mostly on my own; and I've had the pleasure of being able to revisit it recently alongside a group comprised of friends both old and new. It's even more fun now than it was back then, and suffice to say that I plan to spend a lot more time on it in the months to come. [b][u]After nearly 13 years, [i]Left 4 Dead 2[/i] is still one of the best games of its kind; and whether you play it alone or with your friends, you're bound to have one hell of a good time.[/u][/b]

Pros: The game is well-balanced. Every player has the chance to do their part no matter which character they choose. It's easy to find and join MP games, and the community is on the whole pretty nice to deal with.  Teamwork is essential in this game. I like how players will risk their lives for each other. Sometimes you go back to help someone and you get killed, but no person left behind is a good policy. 

No micro-transactions or in-game store items. You want something , you gotta go get it. Just like life! 

Cons: It's difficult to get microphones working. The workshop items can be pretty buggy and make the game crash. Keyboard settings often get reset when you start the game, no matter how many .cfg files you edit.

Overrally, this is my go-to game that I can slip on like an old pair of shoes and start killing zombies. The teamwork feature of the game is amazing. I can't wait for Left 4 Dead 3.

First of all great game! My favorite zombie game ever for a matter of fact! I love the lore, teamwork mechanics, and characters voice lines and the characters themselves. My favorite is Ellis because of his stories and his personality in general. I love the writings on the walls in the safe houses giving more background of the game. The shooting mechanics is a masterpiece and teamwork mechanics. The map always changes no matter if its the same one being replayed. For the teamwork mechanics if you stray too far from your team you might get pounced on by any special infected. I love how the special infected stalk you in the game. The workshop for this game is always active and making greats mods. The game is fully customizable including even the menu. As I say this last part I think everybody else in the L4D community can agree with me on this with the game being part of our childhoods. In conclusion 11/10 is my rating for this game I cant wait for a 3rd game!

This game is simply one of the best game ever made. That is not to say that it is perfect in every way, there are issues here and there but those are just minor things to worry about. I used to play pirated version back when I was much younger, now properly bought it. 

This used to be one of my favorite game, played it all the time, brought some friend along and having a blast together. Then life happened and I stopped playing for a very long time up until recently and I've gotta say. Nothing changed, the same magic back when I first play it when I was younger, enjoying it every single time I come back to it.

Highly recommend for everyone to try out, especially with friends, much better with friends actually, there's a lot of toxicity and elitism going on with the Versus (PvP) scene if you're not very knowledgeable with the game mechanics (depends on the region I guess). Though playing Campaign with randoms are usually fine and fun.
A classic that to this day no other zombie game like it can beat. Just wish they continue releasing content for it but the community keeps this going strong.

Got it as a gift just for the frying pan for TF2, got one hell of a game too. 

I was never a fan of L4D2 but I never really wanted to buy the game for my own money. Although now that I played through it... I will have to say it is worth the money, especially when on sale. 

The story is great, simple and easy to play through. You can spice it up a bit if you want by changing the difficulties. You can also play through the campaign with your friends (like I did) and if you're done with that, there is plenty of other modes to keep you entertained. The characters are... interesting??? (Coach is the best) but you can take some morale out of this game if you take it seriously.  Weapons are well developed and make sense.

The amount of mods, like in every single Valve game, is insane. 
Overall, very fun experience to go through, definitely recommend.

It's fun. Visually one of the better looking source games I've played, characters are actually memorable and likeable which I didn't expect when I got the game, and the modding community is active. The guns in this game feel better than in a lot of other zombie games I can think of, all the shotguns feel satisfying to get oneshots with, sniping zombies before they see you is fun, and the assault rifles can tear through everything with ease and make you feel like a badass. Maps are all great for the most part, maybe minus the swamp one, hard rain is probably my favourite because of the visuals. I enjoy this game quite a lot.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

There's a lot to say, but I recommend it for the co-op experience, the modding experience, and more... This game has massive replayability and also personality. What better situation than to have yourself stuck with a bunch of love-hate teammates. The characters are endearing, the gameplay is engaging, and the community is surprisingly active for such an old game. You can run this game on a potato PC and still get a lot of fun from it. The downside for Left 4 Dead 2 is the never-ending problem of being in a game with trolls, or maybe even on the other hand, people who take the game too seriously; you might find yourself in an depressing situation. But that's life. And this game teaches you quite a bit of it.

This game is one of those older style, level based shoot 'em ups that can be -- in many ways -- whatever you want it to be. With the workshop you're not restricted to playing just what may be considered an aging game. In my game, I'm stomping around as ODSTs from Halo slaughtering flood, or maybe you'd rather run around in a team consisting of a knight, 2b from Neir, straight up isabella in Doom marine armor, and a version of Coach who just has a chef hat on, using weapons with floppy droop physics while all the zombies are minecraft zombies with Alex Jones screams replacing certain music pieces that play when special infected show up.

All in Helms Deep from LOTR.

Even if you don't care for the base game, that workshop keeps it all alive.

One of if not the greatest zombie shooters ever, Left 4 Dead 2 is the kind of video game that you need to play to experience to the fullest.

Left for Dead 2 is extremely detailed, the zombies have hundreds of motion captured deaths, you can damage individual parts of zombies bodies. you can also damage 1-3 parts of them before a zombie dies you can damage them in over 78,000 ways. Each of the special infected is designed around the team game-play, and has a unique music cue. and finally, the game has a built-in music engine that changes based on the unique situation each player is in. 

The game has much more amazing qualities, but are best experienced yourself. If you read this review before watching a video on Left 4 Dead 2 I suggest you play this game blind, it's a fantastic experience.

One of the most hyped up valve games for the 360, no matter how much time I spent on any of the levels the Director AI always kept me on my toes. the AI teammates can be a little frustrating and often more than less slower than dial-up wifi at times, the mod support can help add more functionality to them. maps are beautifully perfect for both versus and singleplayer, the literal night and day differences in the L4D2 and 1 maps is executed perfectly, Don't even mention how well optimised it is, It can play at 1080p 60fps on even a Chromebook! for zombie fps this is a masterpiece If I've ever seen one. whether you use a dollar store mouse, Xbox One/360 or heck even PS4/PS3 controller, Its gonna be a fun time ripping apart endless hordes of the infected. have I mentioned theres over 700 ways to damage one? ya, over 700 damage combos. Just remember, teamwork IS the dream-work here.  theres also mods in this game too, PLENTY of them. they could range from hentai outhouses to whole dang campaigns made by 1 person alone. Love it.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

What can I honestly say that hasn't been said before this game right here is one of the best zombie game's I've ever had the pleasure of playing I played the first L4D way back in 2008 and I got L4D2 for the 360 when it first came out and once I got my first PC a long time ago now I had to get it for my PC and now I have been playing more because of that fact this game is such a masterpiece sure it isn't perfect but this game does what Skyrim or Fallout does it keeps you coming back because of mod's and multiplayer is also a major part of it as well at least for me it is so for those who are new to the series you play as one of the four survivor's and you need to get from point A to point B while grabbing whatever you may come across that could be weapon's such as gun's melee or the throw able one's as well like molotov's pipebomb's or bilebomb's or you could find healing supplies which are medkit's or pill's but the best part is shooting the ever lasting hell out of the infected that come your way blowing part's off like arm's and leg's or their head's but of course you gotta be careful for there is special infected as well such as hunter's spitter's jockey's charger's boomer's smoker's witches and tank's all wanting to absolutely destroy you and your team now if I were to recommend the best multiplayer mode in my personal opinion it would be campaign but you can play it solo which is really fun as well but I think you get the point this game is honestly amazing if you need more proof of that watch people play it a little bit not a modded one by the way you wanna see the normal stuff first which is obvious so that is about it from me as you can tell I love this game it is still the best zombie shooter out there so if you can pick this game up and give it a try I truly do think you will love it alright then cheers mate's and sorry for this review not being to professional

Here we are roughly one year after the release of Left 4 Dead, and its sequel is already out. For Valve, Left 4 Dead 2 represents an unusually speedy turnaround time considering the delays and release date fuzziness generally associated with its games, notably in the years leading up to Team Fortress 2 and the still mysterious status of Half-Life 2: Episode 3. Despite that history and the potential concerns associated with how soon this game is showing up after the first, Left 4 Dead 2 is very much a complete game, much more so than the original, and is without a doubt the better product. If you're still in the mood to group up with friends and slay packs of ravenous undead, then it doesn't get any better than this. However, if you're tired of Left 4 Dead's gameplay formula, the sequel, as good as it is, may not be enough to warrant a purchase. It's a game that's more about refinement and augmentation of existing features instead of offering something dramatically new.

As a result, after you've played Left 4 Dead 2, it's difficult to go back to the original without a mild sense of disappointment. Remember, of Left 4 Dead's four original campaigns, only two were set up for Versus play right out of the gate. It wasn't until Valve released the Survival Pack months later that players got the full Versus experience as well as the now-standard timed Survival mode. Left 4 Dead 2 has five full and more interesting campaigns, a more fleshed out and distinctive setting with some fantastic action set pieces, more personality, more modes, and in general gives you more to do. In many ways, I wish this would have been the product that was released first since it feels much more full-featured than the original, and the fiercely team-oriented style of gameplay wouldn't have been as familiar then as it is now.



It's entirely possible you're someone who never played the first and have no idea what I'm talking about, so I'll take a step back for a moment. It's the zombie apocalypse, and you play as one of four human Survivors who attempt to shoot their way through hordes of fast-moving "infected" (which I'll refer to as zombies) to get to the end of a map. The sequel is set in the American southeast and the new cast of characters is more memorable this time around, as they seem more aware of their situation, chattering away and commenting on specific parts of the environment as they battle through. Ellis' inane stories while huddled in safe houses are a particular highlight as he waxes on about accident-prone acquaintances while mobs of bloodthirsty zombies converge on his position, at which point the others understandably tell him to shut his mouth.


That's not what you should be doing while playing, however. More effectively than most other titles out there, Left 4 Dead 2 forces you to work as a team if you want to win. You need to talk, and you need to participate. Every member of your four person squad of Survivors needs to be communicating about what they're doing, calling out locations for ammunition, weapon, and health pickups, and asking for help when in trouble. The catch is that no stage ever plays out the same way, because there's an artificial intelligence called the Director governing the action. Packs of common zombies can attack at any time, and if what the Director throws at you proves too challenging, your path of progression through a stage may even get swapped around to make things easier. It makes every experience different, and encourages repeat play as it adapts to challenge players of any skill level.


More zombie types make the gameplay even more unpredictable.

Like before, there are multiple difficulty settings, with Normal serving as a good entry-level challenge while on Expert only those with the best communication, decision-making, and reaction skills will survive. Left 4 Dead 2's Realism mode makes the challenge even more daunting, removing helpful glows around items and weapons amongst other things, meaning it's all up to your communication skills to call out ammunition and item pickups or to let people know you're in trouble. If you're the type of player who generally shies away from a conversation and prefers to remain silent, then you're not going to like Left 4 Dead, mostly because your team isn't going to do very well if everyone's only interacting on a minimal level. Because of how much teamwork is required in Left 4 Dead, it's also one of the best games out there for triggering an emotional response in players, which works both ways. If you manage to pull through, you feel a much greater sense of accomplishment, and if you're losing, it can be singularly frustrating since your success is just as reliant on the behavior of those around you as it is on your own personal skill.

Bots are still included, though, so if you do want to run through the five campaigns by yourself that's entirely possible, and should a person have to drop out midway through a campaign, an artificial intelligence will take over so you don't have to all give up. Your computer-controlled teammates will work alongside, making accurate shots, swapping out weapons, reviving, trading items and healing when necessary. It's nowhere close to as entertaining an experience, but it's still functional and playable solo. Ideally, like when preparing for a dungeon run in an MMO, you'll be able to get a full party together to tackle the challenges, and it's an experience that's at its best when in a full Versus game.

Versus is also where you'll be challenged the most, as four players will be running through as Survivors and four others controlling the powerful boss zombie types. These include the Tanks, Boomers, Smokers, and Hunters from the first game, in addition to the new Spitters, Jockeys, and Chargers. The new boss zombie special powers add layers to the gameplay, such as the Spitter's acid pool that can do heavy damage over time to anyone who stumbles into it. The Jockey's ability to take over control of a Survivor's direction of movement makes for even more interesting combination possibilities here, and overall the addition of these new boss zombies adds in a welcome amount of depth and, if you're playing as Survivors, unpredictability to the play experience. If your Infected team is working together you can time Boomer bile attacks with Jockey jumps and Spitter attacks so large groups of common zombies are attacking while one Survivor stumbles under a Jockey's control and the rest are slowly dying in a pool of acid.


These kinds of team tactics are subject to further refinement when you take into account the campaign-specific challenges, some of which are sure to get your pulse pounding. To be perfectly clear, this is not a relaxing game. You're tense and fixated on the screen at all moments, and during sequences like the rollercoaster race in the Dark Carnival campaign and the storming and flooding of the second half of Hard Rain, you'll need to pay even closer attention. The campaigns here include exciting crescendo events and defense sequences that any hardcore Left 4 Dead fan is going to go absolutely nuts over. In that sense, if you're still playing Left 4 Dead and are looking for more, then you're going to love this product.

It's not just the better campaigns, the more fully-realized and detailed environments and the switch from the dark city streets of the first game to the bogs, carnival grounds, marshes, and sunlit construction yards that contribute to reasons why this is a better game. There's also a wealth of little things that make this a sturdier, more complex, and more entertaining experience. You'll find scattered around rooms incendiary and explosive ammunition pickups for all to enjoy, a wider range of rifles, submachine guns, shotguns, and sniper rifles to pick apart your opposition (though many of the like weapons models behave similarly), and perhaps most importantly of all, in Left 4 Dead 2 you can take advantage of melee weapons.

An amazing title, especially with friends.

A friend and I just finished the available campaigns. No burnout, no boredom and very few bugs during our playtime.

The maps feel very distinct from each other, with specific themes surrounding it. The concept of being a movie makes a lot of sense, as every episode feels like a totally different movie with the same set of characters. I've enjoyed some maps more than others, but overall, I've had a great experience in every single stage I've set my foot in.

The guns are varied, some are weaker, some are stronger. We started recognising preferred weapons, creating different strategies and combinations. The teamwork sense honed as every stage was completed. My friend took the sniper and a hatchet? Well, then I'm going for a rifle and a magnum, or maybe another melee weapon - those were common conversations while we decided how to tackle the horde of zombies to come.

The special monsters are fun and challenging. Simple sillouettes, simple concepts and yet you always get caught unguarded by that smoker or hunter, or you think you're smart hiding in a cabin until a spitter covers it in acid and you die. After a few chapters we were already creating strategies to kill the witch (startle and run!!) or signalising different zombies (I hear a boomer!).

This is a MASTERCLASS in audio design. Everything cues a sound - being on acid, being covered in vomit, getting near a witch, starting a horde... This game challenges you while it extends you the hand by giving you hints through sound and effects.

Killing zombies feels very organic, good physics response, good visuals of torn limbs or torso. The game is old, graphics are not as fancy as some titles we have, and still it feels more real than maaaaany new titles we've got in the recent past.

Overall, a GREAT experience that I highly recommend.

Small rant against inconsiderate players. 
I've played this game since launch, mostly on Xbox. Now days, good luck finding a group that doesn't wanna just run around and pop each other in the butt or Rambo it straight through the map while you're trying to search nooks and crannies for pipe bombs and medkits and, you know, actually play the game. That's after they steal all the ninja swords, of course. If they pause long enough to notice one.
When you're done with a campaign and the game time says 40 minutes and the zombie count is under 1000, you did it wrong. It's also a good indicator that you're probably playing with people (or children) fresh from the urban CoD playground and have played L4D a lifetime total of about 45 minutes. 

I rant because in this game your team mates' presence is absolutely essential for survival, and when you've got retards 1, 2, and 3 waiting at the safe house, shooting at pizza boxes on the ground, having the stones to tell you to hurry, while you were busy searching a house for their benefit...   it's just dang irritating. And not at all good for your character's health. Finishing a map in 10 minutes is absolutely unacceptable and a spit in the face of the developers and every decent L4D player out there.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories

Left 4 Dead 2 has been a blast in the past couple of years for me. It is a fun multiplayer (or singleplayer) experience, with plenty of chapters to choose from and unique game modes to play. Every time you replay chapters, the experience changes drastically, all thanks to the AI Director which controls the spawns of the infected in the game, another factor is that each server has different people to play with. All of this adds so much fun to the game. The community in this game is pretty good, not too bad besides some versus players, some of those people are not too fond of new players to the game. The people in those servers would likely kick someone if they did one thing wrong. Aside from that, itâ€™s a pretty friendly community, easy to find friends on the campaigns. 

Letâ€™s talk about the gameplay. The gameplay is like all the other Valve fps games, you run, think, shoot, and live. Itâ€™s easy to pick up and play, especially since each chapter in the game is around 40 minutes long. If you play from start to finish itâ€™ll take you around 8 hours (including L4D1 campaign)

Overall, Left 4 Dead 2 is another great Valve game, itâ€™s an endlessly fun game for the price of just $10 on the Steam store. I definitely recommend you give this game a try! Itâ€™s a fun zombie-killing experience! Left 4 Dead 2 is a game I come back to every year, itâ€™s just a unique game. I Never had a more fun time on any other zombie co-op games besides this one!

Still one of the most timeless games I think exists. If you love zombie games, or shooters and CERTAINLY if you love co-op games....this is a must play and own. I just wish we could have a L4D3.

Left 4 Dead 2 is the 4th game in the Left 4 Dead series, it is the sequel to DayZ.
The game takes place in America post Covid. You play as the 4 last survivors, also known as the only 4 Americans who have never been to Florida.
This is an example of a zombie game done right, not like those leeches from back in the day that made a shitty spin off (Yakuza) or a clunky ass game that is praised for dumb features (Dead Rising)
The game is very basic yet very fun. It has none of that bullshit most games have nowadays like the first 5 hours being full of cutscenes. You open the game, skip the opening cutscene and just play, just do it.
The controls are easy to learn and work very well. There are just so many games from that era that nowadays would feel old because of their controls but here everything still feels smooth. Shooting feels great and the zombie death/injury animations make a big part of it.
The game has a variety of maps, enemies, weapons, playable characters and gamemodes. Not only that, you can also get even more content and create your own by going to the workshop. Which means the game has endless amounts of content.

This game saved my life.

I am 50.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Friend Recommended Me This Game And Now I Absolutely Adore It Just A Fun And Simple Zombie Games That Involves You Shooting Them With A Machine Gun, To Hacking Them With A Chainsaw, To Whipping Them With A Desert Eagle, To Throwing Molotov's And Watching Them Burn. Enemy Placement Isn't Stupid And Actually Random So Teamwork Is Always Necessary, Characters Are Fun, Maps Are Unique, And Guns And Melee Weapons Come In A Lot Of Varieties. But The Best Thing About This Game Are The Mods, Wanna Demolish Zombies As An Anime Girl While Holding The Super Shotgun From Doom Or Play As Raiden Fighting Shrek While Rules Of Nature Place Or Hear The Bully Maguire Theme While Healing While Spiderman Shoots A Dr Pepper Can Well Left 4 Dead 2 Has So Many Mods With The Simple Gameplay Combined With Crazy Mods Makes This Game Fun Or Play This Without Mods The Game Is Still Amazing So I Recommend This Game If Your Looking For A Fun Co-op Zombie Shooter.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories

I don't know exactly how to put it, but this game is just...frequently upsetting. I'm not exactly the calmest or quietest gamer, but at the very minimum, I don't get nearly as upset at any other game as I somehow manage to with this one, and after more than 24 hours of gameplay, I think I've figured out why.

Campaign is fine. As far as I can tell, its balanced and enjoyable. If anything it probably doesn't provide enough of a challenge, but I mostly play versus with my friends in this game, which involves one team playing as survivors, and the other one playing as special zombies.

The game isn't satisfying, or at the very least doesn't leave you with net satisfaction. The dissappointments outnumber and outweigh the triumphs, and any success you experience is just overshadowed by everything that's gone wrong.

It never really feels like you're *winning* when you play this game, it just feels like you're either losing or not losing yet. You just feel absolutely hopeless playing this game, like you fully acknowledge that you're going to lose no matter what you do, but you act in the vain hope of getting farther than the other team. There is no gratification. It just feels empty. Maybe a bleak feeling like that is what they were going for as a zombie apocalpyse game, but its at such a level that the game design itself makes it difficult to enjoy the experience or have fun.

Valve is a great studio. I've enjoyed plenty of their other games, and I generally like and trust their brand, but I cannot get behind this product. Sometimes games like these where its not really that fun are more meant to be pieces of art, and fun isn't the desired experience, and its meant to be more provocative than that, and I understand that, but this game really feels like a game that's supposed to be fun but it just isn't.

Playing this game makes me uniquely irritable. Even with other games, if I get really really into it, and I get really really upset when I die in a stupid way, I'm still laughing about it 10 seconds later. This is the only videogame I've ever played that has the power to leave me in a terrible mood for hours after I've stopped playing it. The amount of time I've spent in a bad mood as a result of playing this game is probably longer than the amount of time i've actually spent in the game.

It makes me get really mad at the game, and it makes me get really mad at my friends, and it starts stupid fights that wouldn't even need to happen in the first place. I always feel really awkward and embarrassed when I realize I'm getting so mad over a videogame. I don't like the way this game makes me feel.

Maybe the game itself isn't innately or prescriptively terrible, but the experience that it provides is. If you want to get more angry at a videogame than you ever have before, if you want to ruin your otherwise stable and healthy friendships, or if you just want to ruin your day, this game is for you. Otherwise, I cannot reccomend against it enough.

Easily the most essential game on Steam. 

Opening Comments: 
This game is POETRY, it is by far my favorite horde/multiplayer game EVER. I love the simple approach to gunplay through interesting level design. Simply put this game is a CLASSIC up there with the best of DOOM, FF, etc.


Pros: 
Great Single player, Great Multiplayer(I don't play versus, but I am aware that the community there is toxic), VERY moddable with some of the most fun mods to experience, Content that after many many years has not gotten stale in the slightest, great characters/story, simple gunplay with a complex mechanic curve.

Cons:

The versus community (from my understanding) is horrible and though i do not play it i will like to mention this here as the feedback on this topic is overwhelming. Now back to Cons. Without mods the game isn't as interesting(personal opinion), Gunplay is simple however, i feel the game could've benefited from a different approach on bloom/recoil; this doesn't break the game, but again just something personal.

Closing Comments: 


10/10 Game with those cons in mind this game is flawless top to bottom and i don't know anyone who hasn't played it but i read these reviews for fun sometimes, so if that is you as well then cooool!! Have fun with your day <3

Left 4 Dead 2 is at this point an old game, and one difficulty with old games is do they hold up, are they worth playing still after over a decade of being released. Left 4 Dead 2 still certainly holds up, and still provides one of the best and unique co-op experiences that not only competes with the most modern games, but in many ways continues to surpass them.
The main selling point of why I continue to return to Left 4 Dead 2 is that it allows full playerside modding and customization. I have downloaded so many texture, model and sound changes that I have not seen a zombie in a very long time. Every normal zombie is a teletubby, while the player characters are iconic like master chief, jack skellington, and the guns are everything from violins to cats. Every weapon model, zombie and survivor is changed, making it a stupid and wonderful experience. More games need this level of customization because it allows for so many dumb and amazing moments while playing with friends. When I want to relax and have a good time, this game continues to have me coming back.
This game was so ahead of its time that it continues to not feel dated. It uses a unique form of AI to control where zombies should spawn and what type based on how the players are doing, and so it balances the experience to make it feel like a fair and unique experience. If you are doing too well, it will throw a big roadblock that you have to deal with, but if you are struggling it might throw you some much needed medkits. This helps keep the game from being too easy, but doesnâ€™t overwhelm you. 
Although this game is old, donâ€™t let that deter you. It is still one of the best and unique experiences to play with friends. While both challenging and casual, it continues to be a game that is worth buying and playing after nearly 13 years.

"Just buy Left 4 Dead instead of Back 4 Blood"

A (relatively) old but fun game, kept alive by a robust modding community (including custom campaigns) and the mayhem that is versus mode.  It may not be the prettiest thing, it may have some kinda wonky default controls (especially on controller), but it's still a lot of fun.
good game please make L4D3 gaben

Ok, whoever made this game is an absolute genius. If you don't have this or the original Left 4 Dead in your library, you are missing [b]OUT.[/b]

Graphics age pretty well in that department, but let's be honest it looks really cartoonish. The infected models are pretty great too.

The story is amazing! There are 6 canon campaigns, Dead Center, The Passing, Dark Carnival, Swamp Fever, Hard Rain, and The Parish.

What I like about Left 4 Dead 2 better than the original, is how it focuses on more of a comedic atmosphere. I'll be honest, it is a bit scary at first, but soon after you start playing it more you will find the infected more annoying than scary.

There is around 9 different game modes, all being incredibly well made and extra fun.

It even comes with it's own section in the Steam Workshop, where you can add plenty of cool and hilarious modifications, or *shudder* the amount of garbage in the Rochelle category *shivers*

ANYways, overall I'd rate Left 4 Dead 2 a 9.5/10. It's one of the best games on Steam so add this to your library if you want a good time!

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, go below, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

this game can be described in 4 words: Cooperation required zombie shooter.

I've played L4D2 since I was a kid on Xbox 360 and I never got tired of the regular campaigns. I started memorizing them because I didn't know how DLC worked back in 2009. Now, that its been so long, and the DLC is completely added into the game, I can sorta live my dream I had as a kid of being able to beat all campaigns on normal at least. It holds its own like any other VALVE game and has the timeless feel that TF2 and Garry's Mod inherently preserve. Well designed maps, great selection of zombies and unique abilities, fast paced when you want it to be, and realistically creepy. Love the blood and gore from seeing a giant hole where a zombie's torso should be. Radical. Also, Ellis is my favorite Himbo of all time. Even the characters are endearing--solid 9/10. [h1] I Never Thought I'd Actually Enjoy a Zombie Game [/h1]

If you look at my library, most of my games are in the management, automation and strategy genres. I like to think. In my recent stint of trying new things, I thought I'd pick up L4D2 since I already had it in my library and I heard good things. This game is certified Awesome. 

I didn't realize until I was scripting my full review for my yt channel that this game was made in 2009. For reference, Borderlands 1, AC 2, and the original CoD MW all came out in 2009. IMO, this game was way ahead of its time as far as polish mechanically and aesthetically. 

The gameplay is so much better than CoD zombies or something. If you're expecting a story experience, go pick up The Last of Us, but if you want to run through and shoot zombies for fun with infinite replayability with your friends, this is perfect, and 100% worth the price, even off sale. 

I would say most of the weapons might feel a bit weird if your only experience with FPS games is playing recent titles, besides the shotguns. I've never played a game with shotguns that feel so good. For a multiplayer arcade like experience, where you can pick it up at anytime with any friends, no matter their experience or skill level, this game is awesome.

Check out my full review on yt if you're interested.

[h1]Often imitated, never duplicated[/h1]
L4D was a game ahead of its time. It displayed what a co-op zombie horde game should be. Throughout the years, so many others either drew inspiration or straight up tried to copy the L4D formula. Yet L4D still reigns supreme. It just has a certain charm to it, combined with a rather straight forward gameplay. And of course the loyal playerbase and the modding community. All the user generated content is what kept the game alive for all these years. It just goes to show you how a game can thrive and stay relevant when the modders can do their thing.

My review:
     - Gameplay: 8,5/10, zombie shooter with less annoying bot than the other version.
     - Story : - the game isn't story based, but you could listen their interaction and other story that you can see in each campaign.
     - Visuals : 8.5/10, the visuals is quite enjoyable for an old game.
     - Sound : 8.5/10, the sound fits the situation very well and it's more better than the last version.
"Again, same with the Left 4 Dead 1, i recommend this game even if you guys play it in 2030 (with exception of closed server). I quite enjoy the experience of this co-op zombie shooter game, every aspect you could explore, and more story you can uncover because the game isn't story based but it is... a story and a film. This is really like the remastered version of Left 4 Dead 1 but I'm down if Left 4 Dead released a new game or new update, I'm always down. I guess there still much room to improve on for developer team, but overall, this time Left 4 Dead 2 is on my on top of best zombie shooter game I ever played."

If you have $10 and a couple of willing friends to play with, then you should definitely get this game, this game maybe old but godDAMN this game slaps. playing with friends make this game just an awesome experience, even if you want to play alone you will still get a good experience out of it. Overall this game is just a certified badass classic. 10/10 for me if ya dont like it then its fine all the same, at least ya tried it. :)

 This game has the most memorable characters and voice lines.

Honestly, it's a cheap zombie game that is equal or better than a lot of triple A 60$ zombie games on the market. It's also really fun with your friends, and since it's not nearly as expensive as stuff like Back 4 Blood, people with less money can actually buy the game and enjoy it, because it's not too long, but it's short either. It gives a good story (at least in my opinion), as it doesn't require a ton of thinking to understand, but it isn't brutally easy to expect the next event. It all goes together with each stage, while sure it skips some of the in-betweens of each chapter, it sums it up usually when the chapter first begins, giving you the essentials to understand what happened. The gameplay is also smooth and easy to understand, and I still enjoy it more than most games as of posting this. As a shooter, it's nice to get into and it's basics are, well, basic. As a horror game, it may shock you a couple times but you can just laugh it off after. 

As a last note, I believe playing it with friends is the best experience for fun, but if you're looking for story it might be easier doing it solo so you don't get carried away. I have zero complaints.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

I really recommend this for new and squad players. You don't need gems, or in game currency to buff your character, the game is balanced by everybody. It all comes down to cooperation, there are servers that buff up the game. I've played this game since I was a kid and this is one of the games I will never get tired of.

Very fun game to play with friends. Plenty of maps and mods to keep the game fresh and fun. The mutations are fun as well. You can weeb your game out with anime mods, or mod the game to have better looking weapons, and player models from CoD games and so on. 
Overall a very fun game, but it does have its flaws (it is from 2009 after all).

I personally like playing with enhanced weapon scripts which make the guns feel more accurate to their in world counter-parts and makes the game more enjoyable and less rage indusing. 
speaking of rage, you will definitely scream at this game, especially on higher difficulties.


In short, game is super fun, wide variety of mods, better with friends. can be rage inducing at times, and can bug out from being an older game.

Even over a decade later this game is still an absolute masterpiece that has, is, and will stand the test of time.
The graphics have a nice blend of realism, retro, and cartoon styles that make this game run smoothly whilst not hurting the eyes. I can't tell you how many hours I've sunk into this game on Xbox 360 and Xbox one, all you need to know is that I loved the game enough to buy it a second time to play on PC. The modding community is still alive and well with some top quality reworks, enhancements, overhauls, and just the plain silly meme mods. I couldn't recommend this game more whether its your first or final game in your library.

It's good game that has its authenticity ruined by gratuitous childish swearing. For me, swearing is for those with a limited vocabulary and children out to shock their parents. It's got no place in game set before such language existed. Swearing is easier to write than meaningful dialogue, so it saves on money. Instead of hiring decent writers who can put emotions into to words it's cheaper to hire second rate writers such as those in this game. It's A pity that the devs did not have courage of their convictions and produce a well written script.

Played from 2011-2013, stopped for 8 years... opened it up again in 2022.

Just as good as I remember.

Charming characters, cozy setting, doesn't take itself too seriously, nothing gratuitous despite 'violent' subject matter. Versus is an absolute blast every time - well-balanced, and when you get into a lobby with serious players for a full match, it's 40-50 minutes of serious, satisfying gaming.

Old-school lobby rules are also still in play: Everyone competes to make the most offensive usernames possible, and to use voice-chat to shock and delight their fellow players with finely-honed obscenities of the purest nature. I, for example, renamed myself to N*****Whipper_5000 last round, to the uproarious delight of my multi-ethic, multi-cultural lobby. Truly, a microcosm of better times past.

Playing this again in 2022 has actually given my score-and-ten bones a not-inconsequential feeling of ennui - Gaming has REALLY, SERIOUSLY, PRECIPITOUSLY gone BACKWARDS over the last 10 years.

This game saved my life.

I am 41.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.
After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you

Honestly I could never understand why this is so popular on pc. The best i can thinm is a case of right place and right time. It has some cool ideas dont get me wrong but most of them seem invalidated by other elements.

All those cool animations and damage models? Good luck paying much attention while being mobbed. Want to use ranged weapons? Most enemies are melee only and run at you so why not just use the melee weapons? Want an interesting experience? Have fun as you just bum rush through the level as quick as possible. And as far as coop once you run the levels that is it. There is workshop I suppose but that isnt exactly unique.

To be fair versus is where this game shines, though there were always some cheese starts that is most games. I remember having a fair bit of fun in versus despite all the other weird design choices.

Maybe I just didnt "get it" but this game is pretty overrated to be honest. Especcially now when there are many other online coop games, and with much more variety.

The silver lining is it is 9.99 these days as opposed to 19.99, at that price eh it is probably a bit of fun. But again plenty of other choices too, especcially on sales.

Great 4 player survival coop experience. with the game being almost 13 years old it still holds up great. the visuals are a bit dated but a "quick" browse on the games community workshop can fix that. A good majority of the maps feel a bit unfair and too difficult even with a full team of adept players. Most of the time me and my friends play on the legacy maps from the 1st game and vastly prefer them over the newer l4d2 maps. 

The Last Stand Update:
The new map is horrible, the difficulty is way to high. the 2 chapters included are both way too long and should be split up into 4 separate chapters. The finale itself is fine although the map is way too large for the gas can section, its hard to collect all of the cans and make sure your team sticks together.

TLS Bug Fixes: 
I understand that this may differ from player to player but, after 11 years of playing this game i find it disheartening that all of the bugs i've grown up doing are being removed. I never really cared for high times on maps but the actions and knowledge required to get out of the map is something thats stuck to me for years and almost feels like part of the game at this point so for them to be removed is sad

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

Left 4 Dead 2 Is easily one of my favorite games of all time. Growing up, I played the SHIT outta this game on Xbox 360. Reliving it on PC was a whole new experience. This game is a masterpiece like no other, with the characters, infected types, and game play. First of all the characters are the funniest characters out of any game hands down. And the little Easter eggs and clever secrets make it so fun. One of my favorite moments, was when I was playing as Ellis and I saw a witch, at a ruined wedding. Not thinking I shot her, and Ellis screamed something along the lines of: "I AM NOT GETTING MARRIED." It was one of the funniest moments, in my entire career of gaming. Left 4 Dead 2 Is truly a masterpiece and deserves another game, directly from Valve.

I really love this game. I have so many great memories from it. If you haven't played it yet, please do. The first time I saw it was when my friends screenshared the versus mode on the first map of swamp fever for me, at that time I didn't think I would love it this much, but after i bought it and played it, I realized how great this game is. Not only is the game really good, but also the mods make it EVEN FUNNIER. It's funny trying to strategize with your friend until they get charged by a charger out of nowhere, BUT IT'S EVEN FUNNIER WHEN YOU (A Greninja) AND YOUR FRIEND (Heavy from TF2) ARE TRYING TO STRATEGIZE WHEN SUDDENLY THEY GET CHARGED BY A ROBLOX NOOB OUT OF NOWHERE. I also love the story the game portrays. I honestly think everybody should play this. It's not just a boring zombie survival video game. It is a very very fun zombie survival game. There is honestly no mistakes in this game despite it being really old. AND TO ADD TO ALL THE GOOD THINGS, IT'S REALLY CHEAP. EVEN CHEAPER WHEN ON SALE.
